bib_record.title: Measurement of cross sections for the 10B(n,a)7Li reaction at 4.0 and 5.0 MeV using an asymmetrical twin gridded ionization chamber

free_txt: 4.5MV Van de Graaff accelerator were
used.
The cross section values of monitor reaction were
provided and confirmed by author.
This paper is first time to report the information of
Leaking alpha. Usually, measure the Forward and
Backward alpha and sum of those two part contribution
as total (n,a) reaction. However, especially for the
target is light nuclei, the contribution of Leaking
alpha couldn't be ignored. As an example, the
contribution of Leaking alpha is 15.6% at 4 MeV in this
measurement.
A twin gridded ionization chamber was used as
the charged particle detector with forward and
backward asymmetrical sections. It has the advantages
of high detection efficiency (about 100%), large
detection solid angle (about 4Pi). The shape of the
chamber is cylindrical, with diameter 28.2 cm and
height 27.2 cm. The shape of electrodes is
rectangular and include one common cathode, two grids,
two anodes and two shields. For the forward section,
the distances from cathode to grid, grid to anode,
and anode to shield were 44.0, 22.0 and 11.0 mm,
respectively. For the backward section, they were
18.0, 9.0 and 11.0 mm, respectively. The working gas
of the ionization chamber was a Kr+2.89%CO2 mixture
at pressure of 1.10 atm. High voltages for the
cathode, grids and anodes were -1100, 0 and +900 V,
respectively.
A BF3 long counter was used for neutron flux
monitoring and normalization. The axis of the BF3
long counter and the normal line of the electrodes of
the gridded ionization chamber were at 0 degree to
the beam line. The distance from the cathode of the
ionization chamber to the center of the neutron
source was 15.9 cm, and that from the front side of
the moderator of the BF3 long counter to the neutron
source was about 2.40 m.

The length and diameter of the deuterium gas
cell are 2.0 cm and 0.9 cm, respectively. The gas
cell was separated from the vacuum tube by a
molybdenum foil 5 mu-m in thickness. The deuterium
gas pressure range was about 3.1-2.9 atm.

The thicknesses of the forward and
backward samples are 21.3 and 23.0 mu-g/cm2,
respectively, and the diameter of both 10B samples is
42.0 mm. Each 10B sample was vacuum evaporated on a
circular tantalum backing 48.0 mm in diameter and 100
um in thickness. The mass and the diameter of the 238U
sample  were 7.85+-0.10 mg and 4.50 cm, and the
enrichment of the 238U is 99.999%.
